nodes.text: Principal Component Analysis using the eigenface approach provides a practical, fast, and relatively simple method for automatic face recognition

We implemented an eigenface-based face recognition system in MATLAB following standard PCA steps (training set preparation, mean subtraction, covariance eigenanalysis, projection, and nearest neighbor classification)
Dimensionality reduction is achieved by computing eigenvectors of the covariance matrix and keeping only the K eigenvectors with largest eigenvalues to form the face space
Classification is performed by projecting a test image into the K-dimensional eigenface space, computing its weight vector, and selecting the training face with minimum Euclidean distance

The published implementation uses a computational trick: compute eigenvectors of the M by M matrix (where M is number of training images) to obtain the M largest eigenvectors of the full covariance matrix efficiently
Training images were converted from 2D images to vectors (example image size used: 200 by 149 pixels, yielding 29,800-dimensional vectors) and assembled into a training set

The system computes the average face vector, subtracts it from each training vector, forms matrix A of mean-subtracted images, and computes covariance-related eigenvectors via the small M by M matrix L = A^T A
Weights (feature vectors) for training and test images are computed as dot products between mean-subtracted images and the selected eigenfaces
Keeping only the top K eigenfaces discards low-eigenvalue components that explain little characteristic facial variation
Recognition similarity is measured by Euclidean distance between weight vectors; the class with minimum distance is chosen
Experimental tests on the authors' dataset showed successful recognition, including cases with some pose variation and across image formats (BMP, PNG, JPEG)

The implementation was tested on RUET student image databases (examples: ETE-07 series), using a small dataset (reported 34 training images in procedure description; elsewhere 36 images of 18 persons), implemented in MATLAB
Authors conclude the eigenface PCA approach works well in constrained environments, is fast and simple, but has limitations handling variation in image size and large unconstrained variability
Limitations include sensitivity to image size variation and reliance on constrained, mostly frontal or limited-pose images in the training set
Future work proposed: extend to real-time video-based recognition, use much larger databases, handle different image sizes, and compare PCA performance with other face recognition methods
